awd_titl_txt: Smart Heat: Aggregating renewable-electric-heating-thermal-storage systems for grid services
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall objective of our study is to test the hypothesis that an aggregated population of smart-heat systems with advanced control can provide high quality grid services while maintaining thermal comfort. Smart-heat systems are defined as controllable, efficient electric heating equipment (e.g., heat pumps) with thermal storage. The social context of the proposed work is that 40% of the US population live in regions requiring intensive space heating, and vast majority of the space heating relies on fossil fuels. Renewable electricity-driven heating systems can potentially serve as a sustainable solution. However, large penetration of electric heating systems will have severe impacts on the power systems such as elevated peak demand. The research team will create a hierarchal control architecture for smart-heat aggregation, and test the hypothesis by demonstrating the feasibility of smart-heat aggregation. In collaboration with several local initiatives, the research team will create a smart-home virtual testbed, taking advantage of high-fidelity and reduced-order modeling techniques and real-world community energy systems monitoring.


Intellectual Merit: We foresee that our research will result in a new control platform to explicitly optimize heating control to maintain thermal comfort and provide grid services. The proposed hierarchal control architecture and model-predictively-controlled load (MPCL) concept will advance our fundamental understanding in stochastic optimization, and will also unite smart grid and smart building research communities. 


Broader Impacts: The results from this study will raise public awareness of two important issues, i.e., the linkage of renewable energy with electric heating in mitigating the impacts of climate change, and the values of thermal storage in renewable heat. The research team will work closely with community organizations to communicate the research findings with general public through community meetings, newsletters, websites, and social media. Together with electric vehicles, the smart-heat concept has the potential to transform and unify our energy systems around electricity. The closely integrated education plan will bring more under-representative minority (URM) students into the fields of sustainable energy systems, built on PI's previous success in recruiting and mentoring URM students.

por.por_cntn:
Electrification of the heating sector presents tremendous opportunities and challenges towards deep decarbonization if electrical energy can be provided by low carbon and renewable sources. This project has contributed to both technological solutions and business models to facilitate the electrification of the heating sector. Technologically, we created three innovations: 1) a “minimal hardware” approach of utilizing only a smart thermostat and a smart electricity meter to perform energy management tasks, 2) a reinforcement learning (RL)-based approach called Behavioral Cloning that enables smart thermostats to perform advanced building control tasks with limited computational power, and 3) a mixed-integer model predictive control technique for effective control of variable-speed heat pumps considering realistic mechanical constraints. Economically, we proposed a heat purchase agreement (HPA) concept that incentives a third-party ownership model for electric heat pumps and could more than double the total value of a heat pump investment relative to the incumbent business model. The series of innovations described above have the potential to significant lower the technical and economic barriers for heat pump adoption, which in turn could provide ancillary services to facilitate reliably integration of more renewable generation into the power systems. Furthermore, the residential energy aggregation market has been long recognized as a major challenge as the hardware and labor costs to install building-level and appliance-level load monitoring devices are usually not justifiable economically for small loads. As smart thermostats and utilities’ smart electricity meters have become increasingly ubiquitous, the proposed techniques have the potential to greatly lower the barrier for residential energy aggregation in general. Furthermore, our research has greatly benefited from the real-world living Laboratories, which inspired us to pursue methods that involve both hardware and software. Doing do has broadened our horizon on cost-effective energy system control techniques. Finally, our engagement with electric utilities companies and NGOs has helped the research effectively disseminate our research results to the industry and communities.
